natural problem: Find the least positive integer $k$ for which the equation $\left\lfloor\frac{2002}{n}\right\rfloor=k$ has no integer solutions for $n$. (The notation $\lfloor x\rfloor$ means the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$.)
natural solution: Suppose $\left\lfloor \frac{2002}{n} \right\rfloor = k.$  Then \[k \le \frac{2002}{n} < k + 1.\]This is equivalent to \[\frac{1}{k + 1} < \frac{n}{2002} \le \frac{1}{k},\]or \[\frac{2002}{k + 1} < n \le \frac{2002}{k}.\]Thus, the equation $\left\lfloor \frac{2002}{n} \right\rfloor = k$ has no solutions precisely when there is no integer in the interval

\[\left( \frac{2002}{k + 1}, \frac{2002}{k} \right].\]The length of the interval is \[\frac{2002}{k} - \frac{2002}{k + 1} = \frac{2002}{k(k + 1)}.\]For $1 \le k \le 44,$ $k(k + 1) < 1980,$ so $\frac{2002}{k(k + 1)} > 1.$  This means the length of the interval is greater than 1, so it must contain an integer.
\end{align}For $k = 49,$ the interval is \[\left( \frac{2002}{50}, \frac{2002}{49} \right].\]Since $40 < \frac{2002}{50} < \frac{2002}{49} < 41,$ this interval does not contain an integer.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes k :: int
assumes h0 : "k = 49"
and h1 : "\<not> (\<exists> n. n \<in> \<nat> \<and> \<lfloor>2002 / n\<rfloor> = k)"
shows  "k = 49"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the least positive integer $k$ for which the equation $\left\lfloor\frac{2002}{n}\right\rfloor=k$ has no integer solutions for $n$. (The notation $\lfloor x\rfloor$ means the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$.) The final Answer is 49
 ### Proof
 Suppose $\left\lfloor \frac{2002}{n} \right\rfloor = k.$  Then \[k \le \frac{2002}{n} < k + 1.\]This is equivalent to \[\frac{1}{k + 1} < \frac{n}{2002} \le \frac{1}{k},\]or \[\frac{2002}{k + 1} < n \le \frac{2002}{k}.\]Thus, the equation $\left\lfloor \frac{2002}{n} \right\rfloor = k$ has no solutions precisely when there is no integer in the interval
 \[\left( \frac{2002}{k + 1}, \frac{2002}{k} \right].\]The length of the interval is \[\frac{2002}{k} - \frac{2002}{k + 1} = \frac{2002}{k(k + 1)}.\]For $1 \le k \le 44,$ $k(k + 1) < 1980,$ so $\frac{2002}{k(k + 1)} > 1.$  This means the length of the interval is greater than 1, so it must contain an integer.
 We have that \begin{align} \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{44} \right\rfloor &= 45, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{43} \right\rfloor &= 46, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{42} \right\rfloor &= 47, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{41} \right\rfloor &= 48.
 \end{align}For $k = 49,$ the interval is \[\left( \frac{2002}{50}, \frac{2002}{49} \right].\]Since $40 < \frac{2002}{50} < \frac{2002}{49} < 41,$ this interval does not contain an integer.
 Thus, the smallest such $k$ is $\boxed{49}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes k :: int
assumes h0 : "k = 49"
and h1 : "\<not> (\<exists> n. n \<in> \<nat> \<and> \<lfloor>2002 / n\<rfloor> = k)"
shows  "k = 49"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: Find a natural number $n$ such that the floor of the division of $2002$ by $n$ equals $49$. If no such number exists, the final answer is $49$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: int
assumes h0 : "k > 0"
and h1 : "\<nexists>n. floor (2002 / n) = k"
shows  "k = 49"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the least positive integer $k$ for which the equation $\left\lfloor\frac{2002}{n}\right\rfloor=k$ has no integer solutions for $n$. (The notation $\lfloor x\rfloor$ means the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$.) The final Answer is 49
 ### Proof
 Suppose $\left\lfloor \frac{2002}{n} \right\rfloor = k.$  Then \[k \le \frac{2002}{n} < k + 1.\]This is equivalent to \[\frac{1}{k + 1} < \frac{n}{2002} \le \frac{1}{k},\]or \[\frac{2002}{k + 1} < n \le \frac{2002}{k}.\]Thus, the equation $\left\lfloor \frac{2002}{n} \right\rfloor = k$ has no solutions precisely when there is no integer in the interval
 \[\left( \frac{2002}{k + 1}, \frac{2002}{k} \right].\]The length of the interval is \[\frac{2002}{k} - \frac{2002}{k + 1} = \frac{2002}{k(k + 1)}.\]For $1 \le k \le 44,$ $k(k + 1) < 1980,$ so $\frac{2002}{k(k + 1)} > 1.$  This means the length of the interval is greater than 1, so it must contain an integer.
 We have that \begin{align} \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{44} \right\rfloor &= 45, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{43} \right\rfloor &= 46, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{42} \right\rfloor &= 47, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{41} \right\rfloor &= 48.
 \end{align}For $k = 49,$ the interval is \[\left( \frac{2002}{50}, \frac{2002}{49} \right].\]Since $40 < \frac{2002}{50} < \frac{2002}{49} < 41,$ this interval does not contain an integer.
 Thus, the smallest such $k$ is $\boxed{49}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: int
assumes h0 : "k > 0"
and h1 : "\<nexists>n. floor (2002 / n) = k"
shows  "k = 49"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Find the value of $k$ for which there is no integer $n$ such that the floor of $2002$ divided by $n$ equals $k$. The final answer is $49$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n k :: int
assumes h0 : "n > 0"
and h1 : "k = floor (2002 / n)"
and h2 : "k < 49"
shows  "\<not> (\<exists> n. k = floor (2002 / n))"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the least positive integer $k$ for which the equation $\left\lfloor\frac{2002}{n}\right\rfloor=k$ has no integer solutions for $n$. (The notation $\lfloor x\rfloor$ means the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$.) The final Answer is 49
 ### Proof
 Suppose $\left\lfloor \frac{2002}{n} \right\rfloor = k.$  Then \[k \le \frac{2002}{n} < k + 1.\]This is equivalent to \[\frac{1}{k + 1} < \frac{n}{2002} \le \frac{1}{k},\]or \[\frac{2002}{k + 1} < n \le \frac{2002}{k}.\]Thus, the equation $\left\lfloor \frac{2002}{n} \right\rfloor = k$ has no solutions precisely when there is no integer in the interval
 \[\left( \frac{2002}{k + 1}, \frac{2002}{k} \right].\]The length of the interval is \[\frac{2002}{k} - \frac{2002}{k + 1} = \frac{2002}{k(k + 1)}.\]For $1 \le k \le 44,$ $k(k + 1) < 1980,$ so $\frac{2002}{k(k + 1)} > 1.$  This means the length of the interval is greater than 1, so it must contain an integer.
 We have that \begin{align} \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{44} \right\rfloor &= 45, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{43} \right\rfloor &= 46, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{42} \right\rfloor &= 47, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{41} \right\rfloor &= 48.
 \end{align}For $k = 49,$ the interval is \[\left( \frac{2002}{50}, \frac{2002}{49} \right].\]Since $40 < \frac{2002}{50} < \frac{2002}{49} < 41,$ this interval does not contain an integer.
 Thus, the smallest such $k$ is $\boxed{49}.$
 *)

fixes n k :: int
assumes h0 : "n > 0"
and h1 : "k = floor (2002 / n)"
and h2 : "k < 49"
shows  "\<not> (\<exists> n. k = floor (2002 / n))"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: Find an integer $k$ such that $k$ is the floor of the quotient of 2002 divided by a positive integer $n$, but $k$ is less than 49. Show that there is no such integer $n$ that makes this possible.

(* ### Problem

 Thus, the smallest such $k$ is $\boxed{49}.$
 *)

theorem
fixes n k :: int

shows  "k = 49"

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes k n :: int
assumes h0 : "n > 0"
and h1 : "floor (2002 / n) = k"
and h2 : "\<not>(\<exists>n. n \<in> \<int> \<and> n > 0 \<and> floor (2002 / n) = k)"
shows  "k = 49"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Find the least positive integer $k$ for which the equation $\left\lfloor\frac{2002}{n}\right\rfloor=k$ has no integer solutions for $n$. (The notation $\lfloor x\rfloor$ means the greatest integer less than or equal to $x$.) The final Answer is 49

 We have that \begin{align} \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{44} \right\rfloor &= 45, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{43} \right\rfloor &= 46, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{42} \right\rfloor &= 47, \\ \left\lfloor \frac{2002}{41} \right\rfloor &= 48.
 \end{align}For $k = 49,$ the interval is \[\left( \frac{2002}{50}, \frac{2002}{49} \right].\]Since $40 < \frac{2002}{50} < \frac{2002}{49} < 41,$ this interval does not contain an integer.
 Thus, the smallest such $k$ is $\boxed{49}.$
 *)

assumes h0 : "n > 0"
and h1 : "floor (2002 / n) = k"
and h2 : "\<not>(\<exists>n. n \<in> \<int> \<and> n > 0 \<and> floor (2002 / n) = k)"
shows  "k = 49"
